loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: A. Hasan was born in 1983. He is single and lives in the Fuzuli region. Hasan earns income operating his own auto repair business, which he started 3 years ago. Now, he needs a loan of AZN 2,000 to buy spare auto parts to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase of spare auto parts

loans.name: Lux Estela

texts.es:
la señora Lux Estela L. M. tiene 43 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive en casa de la mama, tiene una hija que depende de ella y la tiene estudiando.
Lux tiene un negocio de pulperia que tiene 10 años, ahi vende maiz, arroz, frijoles, harina de maiz, manteca, aceite y varios productos de consumo popular.
Lux esta solicitando el credito para surtir su negocio, desea tener mayor inventario de productos ya que en el lugar en donde tiene su negocio solo llegan una vez por semana los vendedores y ahorita no tiene mucho capital para comprarles mercaderia, por tal razon esta solicitando el credito...
Su deseo es que dios reine en los corazones de todos los habitantes de Honduras.
texts.en:
Ms. Lux Estela L. M. is 43 years old, is a single mother and lives in her mother’s house. She has a daughter who depends on her, who is studying. Lux has a grocery store business that she’s had for 10 years. There she sells corn, rice, beans, corn flour, butter, oil and other popular consumer products. Lux is requesting a loan in order to stock her business. She wishes to have a greater inventory of products in the place where she has her business. The venders only come once a week and right now she doesn’t have much capital to buy merchandise. For this reason, she is requesting the loan... Her wish is that God reigns in the hearts of all of the inhabitants of Honduras

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soap, razors, toilet paper, tooth paste, powdered soap, sugar, rice, beans, tortillas, margarine, butter, oil, eggs, bread, cookies, churros, soft drinks, canned juices, dairy products

loans.name: Jocelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is from the village of Solinog Clamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Jocelyn is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jocelyn is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising pigs to sell. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $230 a month from this activity.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 1st loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Balakhan

texts.en: Balakhan A. is 46 years old and sells construction materials in the small village of Agsu city. He is married and has three children. Balakhan has nine years of experience in this field. He rents a store in the crowded square and  that’s why his shop is always full of customers. Balakhan applied for a loan amounting to 1600 AZN to purchase more merchandise to increase his income.

loans.use: purchase more  items to sell

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en:
O. Samnang, 49, is a widow living in Takeo province with her three children. She sells sugarcane juice, making US$8 in revenue a day and is supported by her children who are in the garment factories.

O. Samnang is asking for a loan of US$500 to grow vegetables to sell at the market.

loans.use: To grow vegetables

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou S., 41, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Felino S., a vendor, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling electronic accessories for quite some time now.

Marilou has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow eight times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

Now, with your help, Marilou would like to obtain a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying additional electronic products that she can sell.

Marilou dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional electronic products to sell

loans.name: 03..01.04 Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
"Lieu N. T. (301119) is a 36 year-old femaL. living in the town of Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa.  Lieu is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 03.01.04 Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa (03.01.04 Hoang Hoa ).


Lieu is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, Lieu operates a family member's food business.  The primary source of income for the business comes from making and selling a variety of food products in the local community.  Lieu has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1.000.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2004, Lieu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lieu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products for saL..  She is now requesting a new loan of 5.000.000 VND which will be used to purchase more raw ingredients as before.  The will be their 5th loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Lieu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Hoa (301012) is a 39 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business of making & selling food.


2.  C. T. N. (301036) is a 50 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business of making & selling food.


3.  L. T. Loi (301120) is a 32 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Lieu N. T. (301119) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở  Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa.  Lieu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 03.01.04 Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa (03.01.04 Hoang Hoa ).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Lieu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Lieu kiếm được khoảng 1.000.000 VND.  Vào 2004, Lieu đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Lieu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các thành phần thô cần T.ết để chế tạo sản phẩm để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Hoa (301012) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  C. T. N. (301036) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  L. T. Loi (301120) là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya is 42 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living together in their current home for seven years. Her husband operates a carpentry business. Narantuya is a professional seamstress and has been operating a tailoring business. She started her business in 2007, and has been successfully operating her business.  Narantuya manufactures the Mongolian traditional clothing (Deel) with a variety of designs that her customers requested at her home. The number of customers has been increasing from year to year because of her high quality product. Narantuya is a very open person who has many plans for the future. She says, “My dream is to create my own comfortable workplace in my yard some day”.  She is requesting a 117,000-tugrug loan to purchase more materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials

loans.name: Thaer

texts.en: Thaer A. N. is a 22 year-old unmarried man from A. Hasera, Gaza. Thaer has a grocery store and he would like this loan in order to enlarge his business by buying new equipment.  This will allow him to increase his income.

loans.use: To enlarge his business.

loans.name: Madougou

texts.fr:
Madougou Sangaré est une veuve de 63 ans, qui réside avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants chez leur défunt époux à Mancourani II, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, Madougou s’est vite initiée aux activité de petit commerce de pagnes wax et de tissus brodés  depuis plus de trente ans. 
Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des femmes) pour la qualité de ses produits. Elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes des localités environnantes et son activité marche en merveille.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ sept ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, il est à son dixième prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                      Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 24 pièces de pagnes wax, 18 complets de tissus brodés et 10 paires de chaussures en  plastique. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako ensuite elle les revend de façon ambulante à Sikasso et souvent dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 180 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Madougou Sangaré is a 63-year-old widow who resides with her co-wife and their children in the home of their deceased husband, in Mancourani II, the downtown area of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to advance at school due to societal reasons, Madougou was soon introduced to businesses involving commerce in wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth) and embroidered cloth, over thirty years ago.  She is much in demand, especially by her customer base (composed essentially of women), for the quality of her products.  She receives many orders from the surrounding towns and her business is doing very nicely.  Concerned about further satisfying her burgeoning customer base, Madougou decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about seven years ago.  After several solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her district, she is now on her tenth individual loan.  All the previous ones were properly repaid.  She plans on using her loan to buy 24 bolts of wax pagnes cloth, 18 outfits of embroidered fabrics, and 10 pairs of plastic footwear.  She gets her supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali) and then resells them door-to-door in Sikasso and often in the towns surrounding Sikasso.  Madougou envisions using this loan to make a monthly profit of 180,000 francs CFA, which will be used essentially to increase her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Severino

texts.en: Severino C. is from the village of Nungnungan, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 58 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Severino owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately 75,000 PHP every harvest. In 2009, Severino joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be his third from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Levi

texts.en:
52-year-old Levi J. is from the town of Banga. He is married and has 4 children. He still has children who go to school and he dreams for them to finish college and have a bright future. To make a living, Levi owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Levi has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Levi joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Levi is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Levi from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 37 years old and married with two children.  She has been running a retail shop for ten years and has two employees.  Joyce  joined the Victory group in Faulu Kenya so that she could easily access loans; since the members of the group guarantee each other loans.  Joyce  has requested a loan of 70, 000 KES to add supplies of bananas, maize flour, detergents and other consumer products to her inventory.  She hopes to buy a piece of land and build rental houses in the future.

loans.use: To buy bananas, maize flour and detergents for resale

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes S. is from the village of Olango. She is 53 years old. Mercedes is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Mercedes owns & operates a business venture in the transportation sector providing motorcycle transport services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a tricycle transport service. Mercedes has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair existing vehicle for better service. Mercedes is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Mercedes from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Suyapa Del Carmen

texts.es:
La microempresaria: Suyapa del Carmen Gutiérrez tiene 30 años de edad, tiene dos hijos uno el cual se encuentra estudiando y otro que no esta en edad de estudio, esta microempresaria es madre soltera y se encuentra administrando un negocio en donde vende productos tales como gorras, fajas, chinelas, botas  de hule, camisas pantalones entre otros productos.

Con este negocio mantiene su pequeña familia, según la microempresaria Gutiérrez los productos que más vende son botas de hule y chinelas, además de otros como short para varones y pantalones.

Esta joven madre es miembro activo de la iglesia Verbo en esta ciudad de Bluefields y aprovecha para solicitar un financiamiento para comprar los siguientes productos: 

80 pares de Chinelas compra el par a US 2.30 ; 40 pares de  botas de hule compra el par a US 6 ; 24 unidades de  short de varón la unidad le cuesta US 5.50 ; 52 unidades de  fajas de cuero le cuesta US 2 cada faja ;  20 unidades de gorras cada unidad le cuesta US 2.50  y 12 unidades de  pantalón el cual compra la unidad a US 7.50.
texts.en:
This micro-entrepreneur is Suyapa del Carmen Gutiérrez. She is 30 years old and a single mother with two children, one of whom is in school while the other is not yet of school age. Suyapa manages a clothing business where she sells products such as caps, belts, slippers, rubber boots, trousers, shirts, and other items.

With this business, she is able to support her small family. Suyapa says the products she sells the most are rubber boots, slippers, men’s shorts, and trousers.

This young mother is an active member of the Verbo Church in the city of Bluefields. She plans to take advantage of this loan by purchasing the following products:

• 80 pairs of slippers at $2.30 USD/pair • 40 pairs of rubber boots at $6.00 USD/pair • 24 units of men’s shorts at $5.50 USD/each • 52 leather belts at $2.00 USD/each • 20 caps at $2.50 USD/each • 12 trousers at $7.50 USD/each

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase slippers, rubber boots, men's shorts, leather belts, caps, and trousers

loans.name: Savun

texts.en: Mrs. Savun S. has three children: one son and two daughters. Two of them are garment factory workers and another one is still young. She also has an elderly mother living with her. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  Savun, who has been a lotus farmer for more than two years, is requesting a loan of $550 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting to reduce her transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “KAROLL WOKTILA”; Este banco está situado en el distrito de Huanchac perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Elsa; tiene 68 años de edad, la socia es divorciada, ella tiene 4 hijos y se dedica a la compra y venta de artefactos eléctricos, ella vende electrodomésticos desde hace 24 años y seta pronta a jubilarse, la socia también tiene como hobbie criar cuyes y solicita el préstamo para comprar cuyes y aves de corral para su casa.

La socia agradece el préstamo mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the Karoll Woktila community bank located in Huanchac in the Cuzco province in the city of Cuzco. Elsa is 68 years old, divorced, and has 4 children. She works buying and selling electronics. She has sold household appliances for 24 years and will soon retire. She also raises guinea pigs as a hobby and is asking for a loan to buy guinea pigs and poultry for her house. She is thankful for the loan and promises to repay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela S. is a 59-year-old married woman who supports her family through food vending, farming and sari-sari (general store) businesses. She lives in Brgy. Balisong, Argao, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending, farming and sari-sari store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. 

She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6000. Marcela is now borrowing PHP 20000 so that she can have additional capital. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Marcela aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Magdali

texts.es:
Magdali de 29 años de edad, vive con su hija de tres añitos de edad el cual el papá de la niña le pasa una pension alimenticia, labora como docente de primaria en la Escuela Diriangen  desde hace 4 años en la colonia San Antonio a 15 km de Nueva Guinea, Magdali se caracteriza por ser una joven honesta y muy trabajadora, actualmente está culminando sus estudios Universitarios en Universidad URACCAN.

Està solicitando su cuarto crèdito para repellar y hecarle la ceramica a una habitaciòn que construyo gracias al financiamiento anterior que tuvo con Kivalo cual ahora pretende terminar esta construccion dandole los toques finales y asi tener mejores condiciones como toda persona.  

Su sueño es terminar de construir su vivienda y así gozar de mejores condiciones, que a su hijita no le falte nada y tener estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Magdali is 29 years old and lives with her three year old daughter. She receives alimony from the girl's father. She has been working as a primary school teacher in the Diriangen school in Colonia San Antonio, which is 15 km from Nueva Guinea, for 4 years. Magdali is an honest and hard working young woman. She is currently finishing her university degree at the Universidad URACCAN.

She requests this fourth loan to plaster and tile a room that she built thanks to a previous Kivalo loan. She wants to finish the build by giving it the final touches and making it more comfortable, like anyone would.   

Her dreams are to finish building her home and enjoy better living conditions, make sure her daughter doesn't miss out on anything and have job security.

loans.use: Plaster and tile a room

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth B. is from the town of Banga. She is 47 years old. Lilibeth is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lilibeth says all she wants is for her family to be happy and healthy.

Lilibeth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhom B., 55, and his wife, Mrs. Sarorn Phin, 50, (shown here) live in a small village along National Road Number three about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1983 and have three children — two sons and one daughter. Both sons are construction workers and the daughter is a garment factory worker. 

Sokhom is a taxi driver and his wife stays at home. He is in the process of building a fence around of his house, but it is not completed so he is asking for his first loan of $700 to finish it.

loans.use: To build a fence around his house.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes A. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 52 years old. Lourdes is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lourdes joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lourdes from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao S. is a married, 26-year-old woman. To earn a living, she works as a garment worker at the garment industry in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She has been working in this profession since 2008 and typically earns an income of approximately $2.50 per day.

Sao Sok's husband is basket maker. She explains that he is very good at making bamboo baskets, which he then sells at the market. On average, he earns at least $2 per day to cover their family’s daily living expenses. They married each other a few years ago, but they do not yet have any children. Sao S.’s husband would like to invest in his business to generate additional profits. As a result, Sao S. is requesting a loan from Kiva in the amount of $250 so that her husband can purchase materials to make his baskets.

loans.use: To expand and improve the business by purchasing materials for baskets

loans.name: Cristo La Fuente 1, 2,  3 Group

texts.en:
Graciela is the coordinator of her group Cristo la Fuente 1, 2, 3 (Christ the Source). She makes her home in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their 4 children. She says that her most difficult challenge is saving enough money to buy a house and to return to Haiti. In the meantime she plans to continue to enjoy attending the church.

Graciela is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza. She has had her business for 7 years, which was started with a loan from a family living here before her in the Dominican Republic. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying shoes, clothes and cosmetics products to sell. She will save the profits, because through this business she wants to make her dreams come true – to have her own house and to move back to Haiti.

Graciela's association with Esperanza began because she wants to improve her business and learn more about how to run a business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the rural area surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and irregular electricity.

loans.use: To buy shoes, clothes and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Nhcem

texts.en:
Nhcem S. has been in the farming business for years, planting various crops to earn a living and typically generating an income of $2.5 per day. His wife earns a living selling a few products in her village. This couple has been married for many years and has four children, one married and three single, all employed in various jobs.

Nhcem’s children share their salary to support the daily expenses of the whole family, but they face difficulties travelling to work, having to either walk or take taxis. To solve this obstacle, Nhcem is requesting a loan to add to his savings to buy a used motorbike for his children to commute to their work locations.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for his children to commute to their work locations.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal” SUMAC SONCCO ”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Rosa; ella tiene 43 años de edad, casada y tiene 3 hijos; La socia tiene su negocio venta de mochilas y correas, asocia tiene su stand en el centro comercial el paraíso que se encuentra ubicado por el centro de la ciudad, esta es la única actividad que realiza la socia por el momento, la socia es una persona bien alegre optimista y con muchas ganas de seguir adelante por sus hijos.

La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de más mercadería para su negocio y así poder implementar y tener más variedad de mochilas para escoger. 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota
texts.en:
Rosa belongs to the SUMAC SONCCO  Communal Bank, located in the district, province and department of Cusco.

She is 43, married, and has 3 children. She has a business where she sells backpacks and belts. She has a stand in the El Paraiso shopping center, which is located in the city center. This is currently her only job. She is a very optimistic and happy person with a great desire to succeed for the sake of her children.

She is requesting this loan for the purchase of more merchandise for her business in order to stock up and have a greater variety of backpacks for her customers to choose from.

She is happy to have this loan and promises to honour the payments of her quotas.

loans.use: for the purchase of more merchandise for her business in order to stock up and have a greater variety of backpacks.

loans.name: Kanybek's Group

texts.en:
Retailing of consumer goods has many advantages and disadvantages in local markets. Advantages are that it does not need a large start-up capital and there is always a high demand. While disadvantages are that most of these goods are perishable, therefore need fast sales. 

Kanybek A., 34, is a member of this group. He is single and lives with only person who is financially dependent on him,  a seven-year-old nephew. Kanybek really wants his nephew to grow to be an independent, educated person and he does his best to provide him with all the necessities. Therefore, 4 years ago, Kanybek made his first steps into the business sphere. He used 75,000 soms of his savings to start the wholesale of consumer goods in a market of his home-town, Kerben. He plans to spend a loan from Kiva on investing in goods circulation. He expects to earn 7,000 soms per month, which will be used to make the payments for this loan, to pay health-care related expenses and to take a better care of his nephew. The remaining portion will be put back into his business. Kanybek has fought so that he and his nephew won’t lack anything. He pledges to successfully repay the loan and dreams to open a chain of shops in future. 

      --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods for trade.

loans.name: Srok

texts.en: Srok R., 40, resides with her family in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for angkorean temples. R. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of 4 USD each day. Each month, the family has to spend 40 USD on food and 85 USD on other necessary expenses. R. is requesting a loan of 1000 USD to purchase fish to raise for sale and fish food. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To purchase fish and fish food

loans.name: Pastor

texts.es:
Pastor, de 45 años de edad, reside en San Francisco departamento de Morazán, se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, ganado y pollo, está soltero vive con sus padres y hermanos. Él se dedica desde hace 20 años a este oficio aprendiendo lo básico de su padre, luego tomo clases de agronomía, la producción de su negocio la vende en el mercado municipal de San Francisco Gotera y también es su casa.
Él solicita un préstamo para comprar alimentos para los pollo, cerdos y vacas, específicamente harinilla y concentrado, los fondos de este préstamo le ayudaran a comprar al por mayor los alimentos, recibirá mejores precios y este producto le durara vario tiempo.
Las aspiraciones de Pastor es poder aumentar su granja de pollo y cerdos, ser mayorista y abastecer las tiendas de la ciudad.
texts.en: Pastor, who is 45 years old, lives in San Francisco in the Morazán department, and raises pigs, cattle, and chickens. He is single and lives with his parents and siblings. For 20 years he has worked at this business learning the basics from his father, then taking agricultural classes. He sells the animals he raises in the public market in San Francisco Gotera and also at his house. He is requesting a loan in order to purchase food (specifically meal and feeds) for the chickens, pigs, and cows. The funds from this loan will help him to buy the feeds wholesale. These products will last him some time and he'll get better prices. Pastor's dream is to be able to increase the size of his chicken coop and pig pens, and become a wholesaler to supply the stores in the city.

loans.use: Purchase food for chickens, pigs and cows.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more plastic wares

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda nació en el departamento de Cusco, ella tiene 38 años de edad y vive en la misma ciudad donde nació. 

Hilda es docente y enseña en el colegio de la comunidad de Huayacocha y también se dedica a venta de ropa en el centro comercial “El Paraiso”. En esta oportunidad Margarita requiere el microcrédito para comprar ropa.    

Hilda es una persona responsable que pertenece al banco comunal “Warmicuna Llanqanchis” de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad del Cusco, Perú. La palabra “Warmicuna Llanqanchis” proviene de la lengua Quechua que traducido al Castellano significa “Mujeres que Trabajamos”.
texts.en:
Hilda was born in the Department of Cusco. She is 38 years old and lives in the same city where she was born.

Hilda is a teacher at a school in the community of Huayacocha. She also sells clothing at a shopping center called “El Paraiso”. Hilda is taking this opportunity to request a microloan for buying clothes.

Hilda is a responsible person who is a member of the Communal Bank “Warmicuna Llanqanchis”, which is part of Asociación Arariwa in the city of Cusco, Peru. The phrase “Warmicuna Llanqanchis” means “Women Who Work” in the Quechua language.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
This is Eliza N., 32. She is a resident of Pangarap Village, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Richienel N., her business partner. She is the mother of five children who are all in elementary and preparatory schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send her children all the way through college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents, like Eliza, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can give to their children.

Eliza has been involved in buying and selling of various merchandise. Basically, she buys general merchandise from wholesalers and sells the items, piecemeal, with a small profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, and other items. Customers are attracted to buy her merchandise because of her low selling prices and the many options that are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help Eliza continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Eliza dreams to be able to give her all her children a high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Vahe

texts.en: Vahe N. lives in Yerevan together with his pensioner parents. He produces and trades in linen, blankets and covers. Vahe’s business is the family’s main source of income. Vahe plans to produce more goods and increase his working capital.  With the requested loan, he plans to purchase necessary fabric and other materials. The business expansion will allow Vahe to increase his income and insure better living conditions for his family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and other materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cosmetics.

loans.name: Julia Jennifer

texts.es:
Julia de 25 años, vive en una zona urbana en las Orquídeas (llamado así porque en su originalidad había muchas flores orquídeas) de Guayaquil. Es soltera y tiene 2 hijos pequeños que todavía no estudian. Tiene una pequeña papelería.

Comenzó con un negocio familiar hasta que un día junto un pequeño capital y puso su propio negocio abrió una papelería. Labora sola en su papelería en todo día vendiendo ropa y artículos de papelería como cuadernos, hojas, etc. con la ayuda del préstamo quiere invertir en ropa artículos para su papelería y varias cosas para se ventas e incrementar sus ganancias. Dese tener muchos mas amplio su negocio y asi crecer económicamente par mantener a sus hijos.
texts.en: Julia, age 25, lives in an urban area in the Orquídeas section of Guayaquil.  (Las Orquídeas means "The Orchids", so called because it originally had many orchid flowers). She is single and has 2 small children who are not yet in school.  She has a small stationery store.  She started with a family business until one day, with a small amount of capital, she started her own business and opened a stationery store.  She works alone in her stationery store every day, selling clothing and stationery items such as notebooks, sheets of paper, etc.  With the help of the loan, she wants to invest in clothing items for the stationery store and various things for her to sell and increase her profits.   She wants to grow her business greatly and so create economic growth to support her children.

loans.use: to buy clothing items and other things for her stationery store

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Glenda works hard to support her family. She has a bakery business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from food vending. Glenda is borrowing PHP 28,000 through NWTF to purchase ingredients for her bakery business.

Glenda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream:  to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her bakery.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a carpenter. She has been through senior high school. Mary sells body and hair creams, hair extensions, gari (cassava flakes), Milo (a chocolate and malt drink mix), sugar and fish at Elmina, which she has done for 5 years. Mary assists her husband in the payment of household expenses.

She will use the loan to purchase more Milo, sugar, fish and other things to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to trade in food items. At the time of visiting, she was yet to go to the market for goods.

loans.use: to purchase more Milo, sugar, fish and other things to sell

loans.name: Afiwavi

texts.fr: Jeune dame de 30ans,  Afiwavi  achète du mais dans les villages et fermes du Togo et revend dans un marché de la place.  Elle a 01 enfant. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer  son activité afin de répondre plus à la demande.
texts.en: Afiwavi is a young lady of 30 years. She buys corn in villages and farms in Togo and resells it at the local market. She is the mother of one child. She applies for this loan to strengthen her business and better meet the demand of her customers.

loans.use: to buy sacks of corn.

loans.name: Johna

texts.en:
Johna is 45 years old and married. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock of items such as shampoo, noodles, and canned goods to sell in her sari-sari store.

Johna has borrowed and repaid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for nine years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Johna aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Juana Francisca

texts.es:
La señora Juana Francisca es viuda, tiene 58 años de edad, no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar, tiene 1 hijo que no estudia y la apoya en el negocio que tiene, se dedica al comercio, a la venta de muebles que los compra a los fabricantes y poder revenderlo y obtener un poco de ganancia, inicio este negocio junto con su esposo y hasta el momento ella sigue con este negocio y lleva 17 años de experiencia.

Decide solicitar un préstamo para aumentar su venta, para comprar mesas, sillas, paletas, gabeteros, estantes, roperos, etc. Espera en el futuro tener un negocio más surtido y más grande y así poder generar mejores ganancias.
texts.en:
Juana Francisca, 58, is a widow who didn’t have the opportunity to go to school.  She has 1 son who is not studying but helps her with her business.  She sells furniture that she buys from manufacturers and resells for a small income.  She began the business with her husband and has had 17 years of experience with it.

She decided to request a loan to increase her sales to buy tables, chairs, sofas, dressers, shelves, wardrobes, etc.  She hopes to be able to have more selection and more items in her business in the future so she can earn more.

loans.use: to buy furniture for resale

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 51 years old and is married with two children between the ages of 16 and 21 years old.  His business is well organized and he opens daily from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m.  Jean has 21 years of experience.

Jean has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy more goods such as: soap, biscuits etc to sell.  With the expected profits, he plans to reinvest in his business and to save for his future.

loans.use: To purchase more goods such as: soap, biscuits etc to sell.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard wants a loan to buy more cattle. He is a cattle-keeper who lives in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. His dream is to construct a water reservoir for cattle and to educate his children. He has been a cattle-keeper for ten years. With the proceeds from his cattle business, he has been able to buy land and educate his children.

loans.use: to buy more cattle

loans.name: Khayriniso

texts.ru: Хайринисо проживает в районе Шахритус. Ей 49 лет. Она разведена. У нее двое детей. Хайринисо имеет средне - специальное образование, она по профессии медсестра. В этой области она проработала 10 лет. На сегодняшний день Хайринисо занимается выращиванием овощей для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа топлива и семян лука.
texts.en: Khayriniso lives in the Shahrituz district.  She is 49 years old, divorced and has two children.  Khayriniso has a secondary specialized education; she is a nurse by profession.  She spent 10 years working in that field.  Today, Khayriniso is involved in growing vegetables for sale.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of fuel and onion seeds.

loans.use: to purchase fuel and onion seeds

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.fr:
Né vers 1980 à Ségou, Idrissa est marié à une épouse, père d’un enfant et vit chez son père dans une famille traditionnelle dans la ville de koutiala.  
Idrissa, avec le décès de son frère qui aidait son père à gérer la pharmacie familiale, quitté Soro Yiriwaso(où il était en stage) pour remplacer son frère défunt à la pharmacie. Comme les médicaments font parties des besoins de première nécessité, il est très sollicité par ses clients et sa notoriété est bonne. 
Pour augmenter  son stock de produits, il décida de faire recours à l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans.  Il est à son 3 eme prêt individuel  et les deux précédents  ont été bien payés. 
Monsieur Idrissa envisage de se constituer un important stock en achetant différents produits pharmaceutiques (médicaments) avec ce prêt. Il s’approvisionne  auprès des grands pharmaciens de Bamako et souvent à   Koutiala  si la commande n’est pas importante. Il  vend tout les jours  sa pharmacie au grand marché de Koutiala  à une clientèle de femmes et d’ hommes  au comptant et quelques rare fois à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 225.000FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et investir le reste dans son activités de revenus.
texts.en:
Born around 1980 in Ségou, Idrissa is married to one wife, father of one child, and lives with his father in a traditional family in the town of Koutiala. 

On the death of his brother, who was helping his father to manage the family pharmacy, Idrissa left Soro Yiriwaso (where he was involved in training) to replace his late brother in the pharmacy. Since medicines are absolute necessities, he is much in demand with his customers and he has a good reputation. 

To grow his stock of products, he decided, two years ago, to turn to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  He is on his third individual loan and the two preceding ones were correctly repaid.  

Monsieur Idrissa plans to put together a big stock by buying different pharmaceutical products (medicines) with this loan. He buys his goods from the important pharmacists in Bamako and often in Koutiala if it is not a big order. He sells daily in his pharmacy at the big open-air market of Koutiala to a clientele composed of women and men, for cash and very rarely on credit. 

He expects to make a monthly profit of 225,000 F CFA which he expects to use to reimburse the loan as it comes due, investing the rest in his business.

loans.use: to buy pharmaceutical products.

loans.name: Noselyn

texts.en:
This is Noselyn, 41, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Norberto, an overseas contract worker, and is mother to their children. She, together with husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Noselyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 22,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Noselyn hopes her business grows in the coming years and and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business.  She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “MUJERES EMPRENDEDORAS” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Los Andes, está compuesta por siete integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Olga. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: taller de costura, venta de plástico, tejido de ropa, venta de aji, venta de ropa.

La señora Olga  indica que es la primera ves que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de una compañera. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de jugo de quinua que viene trabajando hace cinco meses.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de azúcar) insumo que necesita para la elaboración de sus jugos; este material lo adquirirá de la Ceja y posteriormente lo venderá en su tienda. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella es soltera y tiene dos hijos.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Mujeres Emprendedoras” (Enterprising Women) is starting its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Los Andes Community Center. This group consists of seven members and is led by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Olga. The members of his Communal Bank engage in various business in order to get ahead such as managing a sewing workshop, selling plastics, making woven clothes, selling peppers, and selling clothes.

Sra. Olga says this is the first time she has worked with Pro Mujer. She joined the organization after being invited by one of the other group members. Olga currently has a business selling quinoa juice and has been working for five months.

The loan she is receiving now will be used to increase her capital so that she can buy sugar, a necessary ingredient in preparing her juices. Olga acquires her supplies in La Ceja and then sells her products at her shop. Working in this manner allows her to generate income to support her family. Olga is single and has two children.

loans.use: to buy sugar for preparing juices.

loans.name: Musu

texts.en: Musu is 49 years old and lives in West Point. She stopped her education in the 12th grade. She is single and has five children aged 18 to 29 years old. For the past five years, she has been operating a cook shop (restaurant) in her community. She likes the way people respond to her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, oil, pepper, onion, and coal for her business. Her plans is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, oil, pepper, onion, and coal for her business.

loans.name: Kamleh

texts.en: Kamleh is a 44-year-old mother of seven children. Because Kamleh is a conservative person, her son Fadi has agreed to appear in the photo instead. Kamleh's husband works at an institution for taking care of orphans. Because they have a big family, Kamleh opened a medium-sized food store in the area to help with their family’s finances. Kamleh and her son Fadi take shifts working in the store. Now Kamleh wants to legally register her store and buy more food products. That’s why she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: to legally register her store and buy more food products

loans.name: Junar

texts.en:
Junar is 43 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with five children. 

Junar has a junk shop in which he buys and sells recycled materials like plastic, metallic, and paper products. He has had this business for 10 years. He requested a loan of 9,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy recycled products like plastic bottles and metallic materials.

Junar has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Junar hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy recycled products like plastic bottles and metallic materials.

loans.name: Jenny Vanessa

texts.es:
La señora Jenny es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora quien se dedica a la venta de ropa, perfumes y cosméticos desde hace 13 años pero en los últimos seis años ha mantenido estable su negocio y ha crecido considerablemente. Ella tiene cuatro hijos de 13, 11, 9 y 6 años respectivamente los cuales estudian.
Ella con el crédito piensa invertir en ropa por la temporada de diciembre ya que tiene muchos pedidos.
texts.en: Jenny is a hardworking, enterprising woman who has sold clothes, perfume and cosmetics for 13 years but during the last six years her business has maintained itself stable and has grown considerably.  She has four children who are 13, 11, 9 and 6 years of age respectively and attending school.  She is thinking of using the loan to buy clothes for the December season since she has many pending orders.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Mwanamvua

texts.en:
Mwanamvua is a married woman with seven children; one attends school while the others graduated. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated a food café business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice.

loans.name: 04.04.6 Nam Ngạn Thanh Hóa Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Quy has a manufacturing business sewing clothes. She is requesting a loan to purchase machines to do tailor-made clothing and repairs.

Quy is 36 years old and she is married with two children.
.
She is the leader of a six-member group, the 6 Nam Ngạn solidarity group. 

Quy lives with two dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Quy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Quy has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Quy has been involved in this business for eight years.

The main hardship that Quy faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Quy hopes to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, to buy a motorbike, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase sewing machines

loans.name: German

texts.es: German, originario de Estelí, de oficio agricultor se dedica a la siembra de hortalizas además de tener una pequeña pulpería en su casa. Los prestamos  que ha recibido de Kiva han sido de muchos éxitos para su negocio su siembra de tomates ha ido prosperando al igual su pulpería que ha venido creciendo poco a poco. El esta solicitando este crédito para la compra de una maquina moto bomba para fumigar un plantío de ½ manzana de tomates.  Ya que necesita controlar las plagas y enfermedades del cultivo y protegerlo al máximo para vender una producción de calidad y disminuir costos. El desea ampliar sus áreas de siembra y diversificar los cultivos.
texts.en: German is from Estelí and is a farmer by profession.  He grows vegetables and also has a small, home-based grocery store.  The loans he’s gotten from Kiva have been of much success for his business; his tomato crops have progressed and his grocery store has been gradually growing.  He’s asking for this loan to buy a sprayer to fumigate his ½-manzana [Central American unit of land measure] plot of tomatoes because he needs to control infestations and crop illnesses and protect them to the maximum degree so that he can sell quality products and reduce costs.  He wants to expand his growing area and diversify his crops.

loans.use: to buy a sprayer.

loans.name: Silas     Odhiambo

texts.en:
Silas lives in Kisumu and his married, he has been involved in Motorcycle Taxi Business for two years. Silas wants to own a motorcycle and has been linked with Community Health Worker in his community. He will support the community health worker by providing transport on set days, this will give the needed capacity to the CHW to be able to reach many more families during counseling appointments and health visitation.

Silas will also use the income generated from his motorcycle taxi business to support his family. He hopes to become a CHW volunteer in his community once he has finished paying for his bike.

loans.use: To buy a Motorcycle for Community Health Work and Livelihoods

loans.name: Dembagnouma 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les  10 membres du groupe  DEMBAGNOUMA 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  N’TENKONI un des villages de DOGO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur 4ème prêt de campagne avec l’institution.
L’arachide est la spéculation cultivée à l’image de  GNINE, 4ème personne debout de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  2 hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau de  N’TENKONI après la récolte à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  40.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

loans.use: Frais de labour, achat d’intrants et  de semence

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel is 53 years old and married with six children. 

Isabel is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Isabel requested a PHP 11000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Isabel has been in this business for 5 years, and has borrowed 6 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Isabel would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: El Crucero Group

texts.es: El Crucero es un grupo solidario conformado por tres microempresarias de éxito, coordinado por Virginia de 27 años de edad, casada y madre de dos hijos de 10 y 7 años. Ella es propietaria de una pulpería desde hace dos años, donde oferta una amplia variedad de productos, Cuenta con el apoyo de sus hermanas quienes le ayudan a atender a los clientes. A causa de que una de sus metas es desarrollar el negocio, solicita por quinto ciclo el financiamiento en la institución para invertir en la compra de arroz, azúcar, pollo, aceite, avena. Con el crédito anterior logro mejorar su vivienda y comprar un frizer. La segunda socia es Jessenia de 36 años de edad quien es estilista y la tercer socia es Migdalia de 48 años, se dedica a la venta de comida.

loans.use: para la compra de arroz, azúcar, pollo, aceite y avena.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: EXPAND FARMING

loans.name: Flavio

texts.en:
Flavio has land mainly produces rice. He uses the land to feed his three children ages 17, 13 and 11. He and his wife work in the fields everyday hoping to have a good crop yield. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and will make a small investment in land preparation. He was born and raised in Baba, but he hopes his children can gain an education and move to a bigger city. His main short term goal is to make all the lands he owns productive, as certain sectors have not been prepared for farming.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Mahammad

texts.en: Mahammad H. is a farmer in Bilasuvar city. He is married and has 6 children. He is very happy that he is the owner of  a small flock of sheep. However, he would like to improve his family 's life by purchasing one more cow and calf so that he can open a farm. The need to buy these animals was why he applied for a $1,200 loan.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and one calf

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new styles of clothing

loans.name: Ioana

texts.en: Ioana is a young lady of twenty-one years of age, married, and has one son. She just finished school and is staying home to look after her parents. Because she needs some money for her family commitments, she started her fast foods stall business, which she operates at the village school every week; pancake sales sometimes serve as a back-up business. Both businesses were started using her $300 loan when she joined the SPBD program last year. She works very hard in maintaining a good profit flow, and she hope to improve her business through her next loans.

loans.use: Buying ingredients needed for making pancakes such as flour, drippings, and sugar, as well as for other foods to sell at her fast foods stall business.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Sabina belongs to the Creative Women's Cooperative Bank. She has a stand at the Ayaymaman Market in Moyobamba where she sells fruit juices and typical prepared foods like tamales and rice and meat dumplings cooked in leaves. She decided on her own to open the business, and enjoys the daily contact with her customers and being able to earn money and grow as a person. With this loan of 500 soles, or about $175, to be repaid in four installments, Sabina will buy the groceries she needs to prepare the food and drinks she sells--rice, sugar, flour, milk, and fruit. She will also buy glasses and table cloths to make a nice place for her customers to sit and enjoy their food. Sabina is 41 years old and has 4 children. She is happy in her work and enjoys the support of her husband and children. She has earned a good reputation for the quality of her food and strives to serve it higienically.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Sabina pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Creativas, se dedica la venta de jugos de diferentes frutas, refrigerios como juanes, tamales, humitas, sanguches de todo tipo, también vende golosinas en su puesto que tiene en el mercado Ayaymaman de Moyobamba en donde atiende a sus amistades y demás clientes que acuden a diario. Decidió iniciar su negocio por su propia iniciativa y por que le gusta estar en contacto con la gente, así mismo generar sus propios ingresos y crecer como persona y mujer. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 500.00 soles ($ 167.00), el cual será pagado en 4 cuotas, comprará los ingredientes que necesita para la preparación de los refrigerios y jugos como azúcar y arroz en sacos, harina para la preparación de kekes, vasos y jarritas pequeñas de vidrio, leche en cajas, y frutas para la preparación de jugos, también comprará manteles para sus mesas y así tener un ambiente limpio y agradable para que sus clientes se sientan cómodos y satisfechos. Tiene 41 años y 4 hijos, esta contenta con lo que hace y cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo e hijos, también esta satisfecha con los resultados obtenidos hasta la fecha, su clientela aumentó, por la calidad de sus productos. Su meta es seguir mejorando en el negocio vendiendo productos preparados en buenas condiciones higiénicas, lo cual es necesario cuando se vende productos de consumo humano.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and glassware for a juice and snack stand.

loans.name: Ibrahiri

texts.en:
Ibrahiri is 51, married with 5 children, and cares for two orphans. He sells charcoal. This is an excellent business as everyone in the villages uses charcoal for cooking. Charcoal is cheap. It is not like the briquettes you buy in the store. It is made by felling trees, which are then chopped into pieces. A hole is dug in the earth and a smoldering fire is set. Banana leaves are placed over the hot coals, and the chopped pieces of timber are placed on the banana leaves. On top of the timber are placed more banana leaves. The entire pit is then buried lightly with loose dirt, enough that the coals can still breath. In three days the pit is opened, and the timbers have been charred all the way through, thus making charcoal.

A person selling charcoal will always be needed. If he can build a strong clientele, he can operate his business for a long time. He will buy charcoal in 100kg bags and sell by 2 cups. Villagers usually only have enough money to buy enough for each day, about 2 cups. So, each day they will revisit Ibrahiri and purchase a day's supply. With his loan, Ibrahiri will continue to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Chinoyen

texts.en: Chinoyen E. is 35 years old, a mother of five, and she hails from Okoko in Lagos State Nigeria. She has a computer training center. She has been in her business since 2004. She needs a loan of $875 to buy more computers and to make chairs and tables available for training students.

loans.use: To buy more computers and chairs and tables for training students

loans.name: Chon

texts.en: Mrs. Chon S., 43, is a widow living with 4 children who stays at home doing her house work. With her business she opened , a pharmacy makes on average around $5 a day of income. To pay for the daily expenses, two of her children are employed by garment factories with salaries of $90 a month. Mrs. Chon S. is requesting a loan to purchase more medicines to sell. This loan is about $1000.

loans.use: Mrs. Chon Sony is requesting a loan to purchase more medicines.

loans.name: Fiorella

texts.es:
Fiorella is a very happy woman who is very affectionate with her parents. At 20 years old, she is already the owner of a call centre. She decided to open this business 2 years ago with the support of her parents who offered her their help every step of the way. This telephone service has become very useful to the neighbors and those visiting the area, as it’s the only phone in the vicinity. With the result of offering more comfort and convenience to her clients, Fiorella wants to expand her business space and add some furniture (sofas). Your support will help Fiorella accomplish her plans.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste.

Fiorella, es una muchacha muy alegre y cariñosa con sus padres, a sus 20 años ya es propietaria de un Locutorio de llamadas telefónicas, decidió brindar este servicio hace 2 años con el apoyo de sus queridos padres quienes en todo momento le ofrecieron su ayuda para abrir este negocio.Actualmente este servicio les resulta muy cómodo y útil a sus vecinos y personas concurrentes a su localidad, ya que es el único que existe en su zona.Con el fin de brindar mayor comodidad a sus clientes Fiorella tiene pensado ampliar su locutorio y adquirir unos muebles (sofás) para una mejor estadía de sus clientes.“Vuestro aporte permitirá concretar los planes de Fiorella, no la dejes esperando”
