Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more clothes to re-sell. Her husband, Mr. Chou Sophara, is a construction worker who could earn a little income to support the family. Mrs. Vannak N. is a mother of three children two of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy an engine for her husband's fishing boat

loans.name: Perfecto

texts.en:
Perfecto D. is from the village of Olango. He is 58 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Perfecto plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 28 years and earns approximately $910 per month for these activities.

In 2008, Perfecto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 29,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Perfecto is requesting a new loan of 33,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mila

texts.en: Mila B., 34 years old, lives in Trento Agusan del Sur.  She started her rice farm in 2008 and it sustains her entire family.  The income she gets from selling her harvest goes towards her child's education and for other basic need of her family.  At the moment, Mila is focused on how she will be able to improve her harvest.  That is why she requested a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and for other farming needs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Second Hand Clothing Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Second Hand Clothing” group. They are small-scale businessmen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,400,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Joseph M. B., pictured on the left. Joseph is age 40 and was born in Makeni. He is married with 6 children.  For many years now, Joseph has been selling used clothes. With his share of the loan, he will buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Coumba C. est une femme de 66 ans, elle est veuve et mère de 9 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BAYOUF-PALAL depuis le 23 aout 2007, elle a une ancienneté de 3 ans et a 6 fois de suite bénéficier de crédit. Elle faisait la vente de fruit de saison, mais à cause de la rareté des produit du à la période elle a changé d'activité et avec son nouveau prêt elle va commercialiser des arachides, du mil et des haricots locaux. C'est une femme très brave et dynamique, elle a pu réaliser des économies jusqu'à acheter du ciment en vue de construire une maison en dur. Son objectif est de subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Coumba C., 66, is a widow and the mother of 9 children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of BAYOUF-PALAL since August 23, 2007, i.e., she has three years' seniority and has received six consecutive loans. She used to sell seasonal fruit but due to its scarcity at this period, she changed over and plans to use her new loan to sell peanuts, millet, and local beans. She is a respectable and hard-working woman and has managed to set aside savings so as to buy cement with which to build a durable house. Her goal is to support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increasing her working capital

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She sells fruit and makes an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a police officer who also earns an income of USD 5 per day. Seang is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more fruit to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to expand the business

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 2 est composé de dix femmes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont un âge moyen de 47 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de N’Gama dans la commune rurale de N’Gara dans la 4ème région administrative du Mali, qu’est Ségou. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et font la culture de l’arachide, du mil et du riz. 
Dans le but d’avoir des intrants disponibles en début de la saison des pluies, les membres du groupe ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Madame Djènè B., qui fait non seulement le riz mais aussi l’arachide, compte acheter avec son prêt, 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 30 kg de grains d’arachide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour, de repiquage et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Konodimini. 
Les activités de labour et de sarclage de son champ d’arachide seront fait par les hommes alors que le repiquage et le désherbage du riz reviendront aux femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie totale de 2 hectares, elle compte réaliser 10 sacs d’arachide, 20 sacs de riz. 
Une partie de la récolte  du riz est auto consommée tandis que le reste et l’arachide sont vendus. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour assurer les petits besoins du foyer et l’entretien des enfants.
texts.en:
Benkadi 2 is made up of ten married women who live in large extended families. They are 47 years old and have 4 children each and live in the N'Gama village in Segou, the fourth largest administrative region of Mali. They met through family and friends, and grow peanuts, millet and rice for a living. In order to have all the necessary materials ready at the beginning of the rainy season, the group's members are seeking a second loan from Soro Yiriwaso. Madame Djènè B. who grows not only rice but also peanuts, aims to use the loan to purchase three bags of complex cereal, 30kg of peanut seeds and to employ staff to work, pick and hoe the fields. She sources her raw materials from the Konodimini market. The work and hoeing will be done by men, whereas the picking and weeding of the rice will be done by the village women. With a total area of 2 hectars, she aims to generate 10 bags of peanuts and 20 bags of rice. Some of the rice harvest will be consumed by those that were involved in its production, and the rest will be sold along with the peanuts. The profits generated will be used to see to family needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertiliser, peanut seeds and labour costs

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes N. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Jolomaynon, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures;  pig fattening and a general store business. Her husband, Alex N., who is 29 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have a one-year-old child. 

Agnes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Agnes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 7,000 PHP helped her increase her monthly profit to 6,000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd loan cycle, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital to buy feeds and more pigs so that she can continue to save up for her future and for the future of her son. Agnes N. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.
http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Bonanza (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Bonanza esta formado por un grupo de 9 mujeres quienes viven por diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta es una ciudad de clima frió, tiene como atractivos sus 4 ríos que la bañan, su centro histórico, sus iglesias, su gastronomía  y su gente que es muy amable y cordial como nuestras socias, quienes son mujeres luchadoras que con su trabajo tratan de salir  adelante  y así brindarles un mejor futuro a sus familias.

La Señora María Elvira V. vive en la comunidad de Hiptocruz que pertenece a la parroquia de Turi, se encuentra en su segundo ciclo realizando los créditos en la fundación, fue invitada por su cuñada. Se dedica hace 25 años a la venta de quesillo (queso tierno) y granos, realiza sus ventas deambulando la ciudad,  también se dedica al negocio de ganado hace 26 años, labora lo días jueves de 6 a.m. hasta las 3 p.m.
La Señora María Elvira tiene 48 años, es casada y tiene 7 hijos, dos de sus hijos son casados y viven de manera independiente, sus cuatro hijos trabajan y le ayudan económicamente y su ultimo hijo estudia  en el SECAP (Servicio Ecuatoriano de Capacitación Profesional), su esposo se dedica a realizar fletes en su camioneta y con el trabajo en conjunto han logrado tener su casa propia. Su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cuyes para incrementar su negocio. Su meta es poner un asador de carnes en su comunidad.

La Señora Bertha Soledad G. vive en la comunidad de  Hiptocruz que es perteneciente a la parroquia de Turi, tiene 23 años, vive en unión libre y tiene 2 hijos de 3 años y 6 meses de edad, su esposo es panificador, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive en casa de su mamá de una manera independiente.
Doña Bertha Soledad se dedica al comercio hace 3 años, cuenta con un puesto propio en el mercado de la feria libre donde vende frutas, hortalizas y quesos.  Se encuentra en su primer crédito, fue invitada por su tía que es socia de la banca comunal, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de aguacates para vender en su puesto, su meta es  ponerse una panadería para que trabaje su esposo.
texts.en:
The Bonanza Communal Bank is comprised of nine women who live in different places in the city of Cuenca. This city has a cold climate. Its attractions are the four rivers that surround it, its historic center, its churches, its cuisine, and the warmth and friendliness of its people like our members. The women are strong-willed, and with their work they try to get ahead to give their families a better future. María Elvira V. lives in the Hiptocruz community which belongs to the Turi parrish. She is in her second loan cycle with the foundation. She was invited by her sister-in-law. She has been selling “quesillo” (soft cheese) and basic grains for 25 years. She makes her sales by roaming the city. She has also had a livestock business for 26 years. She works on Thursdays from 6 a.m. until 3 p.m. María Elvira is 48, married, and has seven children. Two of her children are married and live independently. Four of her children work and help her economically. Her last child goes to school at SECAP (Ecuadorian Service for Professional Training). Her husband makes deliveries in his truck. With both of them working they have managed to have their own house. The loan will be used to buy guinea pigs to increase her business. Her goal is to establish a business of roasting meat in her community. Bertha Soledad G. lives in the Hiptocruz community, which belongs to the Turi parrish. She is 23 years old, and she is in a common-law-marriage. She has two children; one is three years old, and one is six months old. Her husband is a baker. They do not have their own house, so they live in an independent way in her mother’s house. Bertha has been a businesswoman for three years. She has her own stand in the Feria Libre market. She sells fruit, vegetables, and cheese there. This is her first loan. She was invited by her aunt, who is a member of the communal bank. She will use the loan to buy avocadoes to sell at her stand. Her goal is to set up a bakery so that her husband can work.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy guinea pigs and avocadoes

loans.name: Chrisantus

texts.en:
Chrisantus O. is a 50-year-old proprietor of a small restaurant and a fishmonger in Shanzu, Mombasa. He is married to Florence Akello and they are blessed with two children. 

This marks Chrisantus’ first time borrowing from KADET and he plans to increase his stock of fish and perform minor renovations in his restaurant.  He hopes to utilize the anticipated profits on restaurant expansion. 

O.’s dream is to own a large and spacious restaurant in future.

loans.use: to increase his stock of fish and perform minor renovations in his little  restaurant

loans.name: Mujeres Victoriosas De Serro Alto Group

texts.es:
MUJERES VICTORIOSAS DE SERRO ALTO.
DOÑA FELISA S. S. DE 32 AÑOS,  ES CASADA, VIVE EN CASERIO REAL WIT EN ALDEA CERRO ALTO ELLA ES LA LIDER DE ESTE GRUPO  Y TIENE 6 HIJOS, ES DUEÑA DE UNA TIENDA DE VENTA DE PRODUCTOS PARA CONSUMO DIARIO, SOLICITA EL CREDITO PARA PODER SURTIR MAS SU NEGOCIO YA QUE QUIERE VENDER FRUTAS Y VERDURAS YA QUE EN EL CASERIO  NO HAY TIENDA CERCANA Y EL PUEBLO PARA COMPRAR VERDURAS Y FRUTAS ESTA MUY RETIRADO POR LO TANTO ELLA SOLICITA  ESTE PRESTAMO PARA PODER LLEVAR  ACABO SUS PLANES.  TAMBIEN  DOÑA MARIA ROSA C. C. DE 32 AÑOS ES PARTE DE ESTE GRUPO,  ELLA VIVE EN CASERIO REAL WIT CERRO ALTO, TIENE 1 HIJO, ES MADRE SOLTERA Y SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE HUEVOS Y CRIANZA DE POLLOS, Y DOÑA DORA AMALIA M. R. TIENE 3 HIJOS, VIVE EN SAN JUAN SACATEPEQUEZ,  TIENE 30 AÑOS, ELLA TIENE UNA FARMACIA Y VENTA DE COSMETICOS POR CATALOGO
texts.en:
Mujeres Victoriosas ("Victorious Women") Dona Felisa S. S. is 32 years old. She is married and lives in a small rural community called Real Wit, near the village of Cerro Alto. She is the leader of the "Mujeres Victoriosas" communal bank. She has 6 children, and is the owner of a grocery store. She is seeking this loan to expand her business. She would like to sell fruit and vegetables, as there is no other store in the community where people can buy these, and the community itself is quite isolated. She is therefore seeking the loan to put her plan of selling fruit and vegetables into action. Dona Maria Rosa C. C., also 32, is also a member of the group. She too lives in Real Wit, Cerro Alto. She is the single mother of one son, and she dedicates her time to raising chickens and selling eggs. Dona Dora Amalia M. R., the third member of the group, has 3 children. She is 30 years old and lives in San Juan Sacatepequez. She has a drugstore and also sells cosmetics through a catalogue.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Productos de consumo diario

loans.name: Ignace

texts.en:
Ignace is 29 years and single. Ignace lives with his parents and he has to contribute to supporting his family. That's the reason why he works hard so as to provide whatever they need in his family. Apart from that, Ignace owns a business selling various products for his store. This store sells various products such as:  rice; cosmetic products; has computers for secretarial services and so on. Ignace’s business is known and organized. This is his 5th year of successful operation of his business. The hours of his business are from are from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except Saturdays.

Ignace is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business which will make him more efficient. With this expansion, Ignace will be able to satisfy his customers who will allow him to earn more profits to be used in his business and in his family.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima M. sells 'banku' at Nyinasi near Abura. She is married and has nine children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She sells 'banku' and okra stew, which she prepares by soaking corn in water and then milling it together with cassava. She uses that in preparing her 'banku' for sale. She will use the loan to buy more corn and cassava to mill for preparing her 'banku', and also buy more vegetables and spices to cook her stew.

Fatima will use the profits she gets to further her children’s education and also for the upkeep of her home. She will also use the rest of the profits to add to her capital for continuing her cooked food business.

loans.use: buy more corn and cassava to mill for preparing 'banku' and also more vegetables and spices to cook her stew

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 25 years old and single. Marie lives with her parents and she has to contribute to her family by providing all necessities for the family. Marie owns a business selling clothes and she is a tailor sometime. Marie employs three people as helpers from her community and the hours of her business are from 7 AM to 6 PM.	

Marie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase more clothes and others clothing items for sale. With this loan, Marie needs to earn much money to use in her business. With the extra money, Marie will be able to save, which will allow her to get married in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and another items

loans.name: Beatrice Jepkorir

texts.en:
Beatrice Jepkorir C. is 23 years old, married. They have one child who is three years. There residential place is in Kapsowar, in Eldoret Town. Beatrice sells second hand clothes and has been in this business for the past two years. She earns a monthly profit of Kshs.10,000.

Beatrice learned about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area. She is applying for her second loan of  60,000 Ksh. from KADET LTD, which she intends to use to buy six bales of second hand clothes. With the anticipated profits, she plans to save and purchase a plot of land.

In future Beatrice wishes to expand her business and also built rental houses. Her deeper desire is to see her child realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy six  bales of second hand clothes.

loans.name: Myla

texts.en:
Myla P. is from the village of Alimannao, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 30 years old. Myla is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Myla provides water refilling services to local community members. Myla has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Myla joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Myla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. Myla is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used for additional inventory and as working capital for the business. This will be the second loan taken by Myla from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to financially support her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is married and a mother to four children who are in school. She operates a food stall in a busy part of Nairobi and her main customers are taxi drivers and conductors. She is 38 years old and has two employees. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kes to purchase ingredients for cooking. She describes herself as hardworking and patient and hopes to own a big hotel in the future. In five years, Alice plans to have built her own business premises.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Alberto

texts.es: Alberto, de 27 años, convive con Haydee, de 25 años. Ambos tienen 2 hijos: Jefferson, de 6 y Renzo de un año de edad. En unión familiar ellos en su casa propia, ubicada en la localidad de Ricrican. La actividad económica de esté trabajador hombre, es la agricultura. Sus principales cultivos constan de tubérculos como: papa y olluco; “mis padres me enseñaron todo lo necesario, sobre las técnicas de cultivo”, menciona. Los buenos cuidados que le ofrece constantemente a sus sembríos, hacen que sus cosechas sean buenas y con mucha demanda en el mercado central de la ciudad de Tarma. Ya tiene 10 años dedicándose a está ardua labor; y ahora Alberto, no solo sigue sembrando, también compró varias cabezas de carneros, los que ahora ya están creciendo fuertes y saludables. Seguro de la voluntad y la fuerza que tiene, ahora él está invirtiendo más en la mejora de sus cultivos. Esté es el noveno crédito con MFP, y como integrante de su banco comunal, es una persona responsable y muy trabajadora. Con el monto que solicita comprará 10 sacos de abono orgánico, que oscila entre los 100 soles cada uno, y si el crédito le alcanza invertirá en el mantenimiento de sus terrenos agrícolas; para ello necesitará peones, que tendrá que contratar para que le ayuden en la limpieza de la maleza que crece en el campo.
texts.en:
Alberto is 27 years old.  He lives with his partner, 25 year-old Haydee.  Together they have 2 children: 6 year-old Jefferson and 1 year-old Renzo.  They live in their own home which is located in the town of Ricrican.  This hard-working man is a farmer.  His main crops are tubers such as potatoes and 'olluco' (a native tuber).  "My parents taught me everything I needed to know about cultivation techniques", he says.

The good care that Alberto constantly takes of his crops means that his harvests are good and are in great demand in Tarma's central market.  He has been doing this hard work for 10 years.  Now Alberto not only continues growing crops but he also bought several rams which are now growing strong and healthy.  Alberto is certain of the willpower and strength that he has and so he is investing some more in improving his crops.

This is Alberto's ninth loan with MFP and he is a responsible and very hard-working member of his community bank.  He will use his loan money to buy 10 sacks of organic fertilizer which costs around 100 Peruvian soles a sack and, if the loan money stretches far enough, he will also invest in maintaining his farmland.  For this, he needs laborers who he will hire to help clear the weeds that are growing on his land.

loans.use: To buy 10 sacks of organic fertilizer and to hire laborers to help him weed his land

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, beans, meat, fish, pepper, salt, and oinions

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is 42 year-old widowed mother who lives with her two children, ages 17 and 13, in the S. district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house with a fence. Her oldest daughter attends a construction college while her youngest son attends a secondary school. 

Her husband passed away and she supports her two children by operating a mobile meal selling business. She cooks a variety of meals and foods in a rented space and delivers these hot meals to the markets and office buildings according to her customers' orders. She started her business in 2007 and has since built a stable operation. She has hired an additional worker for her cafe. 

Purevsuren says, "all I want to do is provide a higher education for my two children." For the future, she plans to open her own cafe. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to add to her working capital and to purchase and preserve a large amount of meat for her meal making business.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve a large amount of meat.

loans.name: Havas

texts.en:
B. Havas works with her husband in a business buying and reselling cows.  She has 4 children. Havas would like to request a loan of USD 1,500 in order to purchase additional cows to increase her inventory and meet customer demands. She believes this will lead to greater revenue, and  ultimately greater profit for her family. 

In the future, she would like to reinvest the earnings generated by this loan back into her business to purchase additional cows and increase their income further. Havas plans to use the increased income to fund her children’s education. 

You can become an important part in Havas family's life.  She deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Horn's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members. They are located in Chheu Khmau village in Kandal province. Mrs. Horn S. was born in 1979 and is married.  She was selected to be the group leader by the other members. 

She and her husband, Mr. Lim Sok Chea, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow rice for the family's living. The farming does not bring in enough money to increase its yield. So Horn S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and pesticide to help grow rice.   In addition to farming, her husband earns his living by fishing. 

This couple has three children. Two are attending the local school and the youngest one is 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, gasoline, and pesticide for growing rice.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more goods for his general store

loans.name: Mahabbat

texts.en:
Mahabbat H. is a married man who lives with his family in Bilasuvar. He is 32 years old and the father of two children 7 and 9.  Mahabbat makes a living breeding cattle and selling meat and dairy products in the Bilasuvar bazaar and his wife helps him in his business. Before he started his business in 2006, his family lacked the means to cover all their expenses. Since then the business has been the only source of income for the family. 

This is the first loan Mahabbat has received from Aqroinvest and KIVA. He used this loan of 1000 AZN to buy two cows and feed them. After repaying this loan, he plans to take out another loan to expand his business. Mahabbat thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy two cows

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 45 years old and married with four children.

Mercy works hard to provide for her family. She buys and sells vegetables and spices in the Philippines and requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more spices.

Mercy has borrowed and paid back 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been buying & selling vegetables and spices for five years and also earns an income from hog raising.

Mercy aspires to save for the future education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables and spices

loans.name: Lukia

texts.en:
Lukia N. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Lukia has a small retail shop, which she has had for five years.  She also has a second business: a restaurant.  

To help expand her business, Lukia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential merchandise like sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lukia hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, Lukia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential goods like sugar for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 30 years old and is married with one child who is three years old. Rose sells mobile phones. Her business is well-organized. Rose has three years experience and she works from 8am until 9pm every day. 

Rose has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase more mobile phones to sell. With this loan, Rose expects to create new business that will allow her to save for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more mobile phones to sell.

loans.name: Sussy

texts.es:
La Sra. Sussy pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 32 años y dos  hijos en edad escolar  

Estudió alta costura y diseño de modas, por  iniciativa propia y con el apoyo de sus cónyuge   hace 13 años se dedica a la costura, su capital de inicio fue  de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles. Sus clientes son los trabajadores de  instituciones públicas, privadas,  vecinos, amigos y familiares.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, comprará  telas en fardos de diferentes colores y diseños variados,   hilos de coser, agujas, entre otros materiales  para continuar dando un servicio  de calidad a sus clientes. 

Sussy  se considera una mujer emprendedora, su sueño es contar con una empresa de la alta costura.  Está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse y salir adelante.
texts.en:
Sussy is a member of the ‘Virgen de la Inmaculada’ Communal Bank, located in the District of Tarapoto within the Province and Department of San Martín. She is 32 years old, single, and has two school-aged children.

She studied haute couture and fashion design. As a result of her own initiative and the support of her husband, she has worked in sewing for 13 years, starting with 500 Peruvian Nuevos Soles (PEN) in capital. Her customers are employees of public and private institutions, neighbors, friends and relatives.

With this loan of 3,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles (PEN), she will purchase bundles of fabrics in different colors and designs, sewing thread, needles, and other materials to continue providing quality service to her customers.

Sussy considers herself to be an enterprising woman and her dream is to have a high fashion business. She is very grateful to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her to have opportunities to improve and get ahead.

loans.use: to buy bundles of fabrics in different colors and designs, sewing thread, needles, and other materials.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es: Ruth, de 39 años de edad, convive con su pareja Valentín de 42 años y tienen cinco hijos en etapa escolar. Juntos residen en la ciudad de Santa Rosa, donde tienen su propio techo construido a base de material rústico. Cuando ella visualizó las tiendas de abarrotes de su amiga y de sus vecinas, vio que era lo que deseaba, pero entonces era adolescente, y sus estudios se truncaron debido a que sus padres no le ayudaron a cubrir sus gastos educativos. Es así que Ruth empezó a trabajar como jornalera en distintas chacras, durante un buen tiempo, y con el dinero que percibía pudo ahorrar un dinero para cumplir su deseo de tener una tienda. Actualmente, se encuentra feliz y tranquila al ver que sus sueños se cristalizaron, además que le esta yendo muy bien en las ganancias y esto es por que tiene variedad de productos que ofrecer a su clientela. Normalmente trabaja por cuenta propia, pero en ocasiones recibe la ayuda de sus hijos. Su punto de venta lo realiza en el mercado de su propia localidad. Por tanto espera mejorar cada día más y para ello necesita de su ayuda para que pueda abastecer su tienda, así podrá competir con los demás comerciantes y mantener a su clientela. Este es su sexto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con su cronograma de pagos, además está conforme con su banco comunal, ya que todos cumplen con sus compromisos de pago. Con el crédito solicitado comprará sacos de arroz, azúcar, detergentes y golosinas.
texts.en: Ruth is 39 years old. She lives with her husband Valentín, who is 42. They have five school aged children.  They live together in the city of Santa Rosa, where they have their own home built from rustic materials. When she saw the grocery stores that her friend and neighbors had, she saw what she wanted. She was a teenager then, and her studies were truncated because her parents didn't help her cover her education costs. That's how Ruth started to work as a day laborer in different fields for some time. With the money she was able to save up she was able to make her dream of opening a store come true. At present, she is happy and at peace seeing that her dreams are taking shape. In addition, her earnings are going very well, and this because she has a variety of products to offer her customers. Normally, she works on her own, but occasionally she has her children's help. Her point of sale is in the market of her own community. She hopes to improve more every day and for that she needs your help so she can supply her store and be able to compete with the other merchants and keep her customers. This is her sixth loan with MFP, and she is committed to continuing making her payments on time. She is also happy with her community bank, since all of them make their payments. With the loan she has asked for, she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, detergents and candies.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice and sugar, cleaning products and candies.

loans.name: Crispy

texts.en:
Crispy is 31 years old and married with three children. Crispy has been raising pigs for twelve years and also earns additional income from selling Avon products.

Crispy is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia sells cloth, candles, steel wool, sugar, groundnuts and other items at Elmina, a fishing community in Cape Coast. She has senior high level of education. When the loan comes, she says will be used to buy more candles, steel wool and other items to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a shop some day.

loans.use: to buy more candles, steel wool and other items to sell.

loans.name: Mzia

texts.en:
Mzia comes from West Georgia, village Zeda Meskheti. She is 54 years old, married, and lives with her husband Temur and two adult sons (32 and 25 years old). The younger son is a sportsman. Mzia’s elder son has health problems and gets a pension from the government in the amount of 70 GEL per month. The only source of the income for the family is agriculture. In particular, they own a plot of land, where cucumbers and greens are grown. Harvested products are sold at a local market. Mzia’s family also has a small dairy farm with 3 cows. Mzia produces and sells approximately 50 kg of cheese per month in the local open market. 

Though Mzia and Temur work hard on their farm, their income is still not enough to make some savings for renovation of the house. Because of this reason, she requested the credit to start renovation work. The borrowed amount will be enough to renovate the bathroom. It will add comfort to family’s everyday life.

loans.use: to purchase materials for bathroom renovation and pay the workers

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane lives in Uganda. She is married and has seven children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).

Jane has a mini-bakery. She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days out of every week. Jane sells her products at retail in the market.

She has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more cartons of baking flour, cow peas, and cooking oil.

The main business challenges for Jane include seasonality, the ever-increasing price of cooking oil, and theft. Her goals for her business are to own a fully stocked bakery. Jane lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but not piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and medication.

loans.use: to buy cartons of baking flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Arselia Epifania

texts.es: El Sra. Arselia nació en Araní Cochabamba tiene cuatro  hijos algunos ya independientes,  su esposo es el Sr.  Fernando,  hace 40 años que se vinieron a la guardia en busca de mejores oportunidades dejando su ciudad natal y mediante el sindicato de pequeños comerciantes del mercado tienen un pequeño puesto en el mismo,  en la cual  trabaja en la venta de desayuno se levanta a tempranas horas de la mañana para preparar sus alimentos y su esposo se dedica a la carpintería en su domicilio,  hace 30 años que  esta trabajando como carpintero y a veces se dedica  preparar la masa para las empanadas ya que ella elabora sus propias empanadas,  para llevarlo al mercado ayudando así a su esposa mayormente lo hace los fines de semana, ya que ella cuenta con una ayudante pero esos días se necesita mas manos en lo que es la preparación ya que ella elabora empanada de pollo, queso, masaco, pastel de choclo, yuca, etc. Con el dinero del credito comprara harina por mayor, Es una persona muy trabajadora agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Sra. Arselia was born in Araní Cochabamba and has four children, some of whom are already independent. Her husband is Sr. Fernando, age 40. They left her hometown and came to La Guardia in search of better opportunities. After joining a union of small merchants, Arselia was able to acquire a vending post at the market. Her work involves selling breakfast, so she wakes up in the early hours of the morning so that she can prepare the food. Her husband works from home as a carpenter and has been in this profession for 30 years. Sometimes he helps with preparing the dough, while Arselia is busy making her empanadas to take to the market. She works mainly on the weekends. Recently Arselia hired an assistant because she needs more hands for making empanadas filled with chicken, cheese, mashed plantains, sweet corn, cassava, and other items.

The money from this loan will be used to buy flour in bulk. Arselia is a hardworking individual and is grateful to Emprender for the support it has provided.

loans.use: to buy flour in bulk.

loans.name: Christ

texts.en:
Christ, 27, is married to Yandri, 29. She is originally from Java Island. In their marriage, Christ and Yandri have been blessed with two children: Esra, 4 years old; and Dwi, 2 years old. Christ and her children are living with her mother-in-law, as her husband is working in another district. 

In order to help her husband in generating money for their family, Christ runs a kiosk business. Prior to running the business, Christ used to sell mobile phone recharges and cakes. She usually operates her business from 5:00 a.m. until 23:00 p.m. every day. 

Christ desires to improve her business by adding more items to sell, e.g., various snacks and beverages, ice cream, and mobile phone recharges, as demanded by her customers. Christ thinks that the more stuff that she offers, the more customers will like to come to her kiosk. Therefore, Christ is requesting a loan amounting to 4,500,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR) from TLM. She is hoping that TLM will assist her in making her dreams come true.

loans.use: to buy various snacks, beverages, ice cream, and mobile phone recharges to sell

loans.name: Araba

texts.en:
Araba is showing the maize she uses to make kenkey in Ayensudu near Elmina. She also sells “gboma”, as this dish is locally called by people from the Volta region of Ghana.  Gboma looks like spinach used in preparing food. 

Araba is married and has 3 children. Her partner is a farmer. Araba has been selling kenkey for 12 years. She assists her husband in taking care of the home.  Her loan will be used to buy maize in sacks to cook to sell. She hopes to use the new earnings from her business to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: buy maize

loans.name: Kevin Kyazo

texts.en: Kevin is a single man. He describes himself to be cheerful and kind. He operates a second hand clothing store where he sells trousers for men and women, and skirts for women. He has been involved in this business for one year. He describes his biggest business challenges to be sourcing new stock and staying familiar with fashion trends. He will use the KES 10,000 loan to increase the stock for the store. His business goal is to improve his business premises within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will have more than one outlet to sell his products.

loans.use: To increase his stock of second hand clothes

loans.name: Greta Yolanda

texts.es:
Greta Yolanda tiene 43 años de edad es soltera no tiene hijos vive sola en el Cantón Chillanes Provincia Bolívar.
La VRC Unión y Progreso la Colombia baja, está conformada por quince integrantes y está ubicada a 90 minutos de la cooperativa esta ventanilla se dedica a Actividades Agrícolas, siembra de cacao, arroz, maíz, Soya plátano, naranja, etc.
Greta  se dedica a la agricultura, a la siembra de cacao arroz, maíz, soya, naranja, las compras y las ventas lo realiza en San José del Tambo cada fin de semana.
 Solicita el crédito para poder comprar semillas, abonos e insumos para los cultivos y también invertir en la compra de cerdos para la cría y luego venderlos. 
Con la ayuda del préstamo le ayudará a suplir necesidades económicas, Enfrenta desafíos que son muy frecuentes como la competencia y las plagas. 
El sueño es poderse comprar terrenos para poder sembrar cacao y comprar insumos, abonos, fertilizantes.
En los tiempos libres le gusta salir a visitar a los padres.
texts.en:
Greta Yolanda is 43 years old.  She is single and doesn't have any children.  She lives alone in Chillanes canton, in Bolívar province.

The 'Unión y Progreso la Colombia Baja' community bank has fifteen members and is located 90 minutes from our cooperative.  The members of this bank work in agriculture, growing cacao, rice, corn, soy, bananas, oranges, etc.

Greta is a farmer who grows cacao, rice, corn, soy and oranges.  She makes her purchases and sales in San José del Tambo every weekend.

Greta is requesting this loan to buy seeds, manure and supplies for her crops.  She will also invest in buying pigs to raise and then sell.

The support of this loan will help Greta to financially cover her needs.  She faces very frequent challenges in the form of competition and pests.

Greta's dream is to buy land so that she can sow cacao.

In her free time, Greta enjoys going to visit her parents.

loans.use: to buy seeds, manure and supplies for her crops, and to buy some pigs to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a mortorbike to transport the weaving products to sell

loans.name: Luis Alfredo

texts.es:
Luis de 19 años, un joven trabajador que tiene aspiraciones de crecimiento de negocio.
Su negocio es una tienda, inicio esta actividad hace 5 años, con su hermano.
Esta actividad la realiza con su hermano,  no tiene hijos y  está casado.
La dificultad de él es la delincuencia ya que fue víctima de un robo en la salida de su negocio.
El solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercadería como: arroz, legumbres, bebidas, etc.
Su sueño es incrementar su negocio.
texts.en:
Luis is 19 years old.  He is a hard-working young man who aspires to grow his business - a store.  He started his business five years ago with his brother.  He works with his brother.  Luis is married and does not have any children.

Luis' problem is crime as he was robbed outside his business.  He is requesting this loan to buy merchandise such as rice, vegetables, drinks, etc.  His dream is to increase his business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as rice, vegetables, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Eufemio Nicolas

texts.es:
Don Eufemio sigue avanzando con su negocio, el cual cambio, una pulperia por el negocio de venta de gas de tropigas, asi como mejoro un poco un pequeño cyber, que ahora esta en mejores condiciones de servicio, pues esta al frente del negocio, ahora en su casa.
Sus tres hijos cursan el año escolar, y su esposa lo apoya en el negocio.  Hoy con este nuevo prestamo necesita ampliar y terminar el local, donde pondra el cyber, logrando tener mas espacio en la sala ya que no ha mejorado las condiciones, privando a su familia, pero siendo para el bien comun de todo. Podra con este prestamo hacer la mejora y cerrar un anexo que avenido haciendo con ahorro de las ganacias. Mejorando las condicion de vivienda y dando un mejor servicio a su clientela.
texts.en:
Don Eufemio continues to advance in his business. He is converting his store into a business selling fuel for Tropigas (a Latin American energy company). Eufemio has also made a slight improvement to his business by adding a small cybercafé. He now has better conditions to provide this service since the business is in his home.

His three children attend school and his wife helps with the business. Today with this new loan, he needs to expand and finish the space where the cybercafé will be located. Providing more space for his business will create better conditions for his family and the common good of everyone. With this loan, Eufemio will be able to make improvements. He will then use the savings from his income to close off the annex. In the end, he will improve the condition of his home and provide better service to his customers.

loans.use: to purchase materials to build a space in his home for a cybercafé.

loans.name: Bayaraa

texts.en:
Bayaraa is 26 years old and lives with his wife in ger (Mongolia tent) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. 

His wife is a kindergarten teacher. 

He started his plumbing business in 2010.  Since then, his business has been successful and he is well known for his low-cost and reliable service. 

His service is very convenient because he even takes on late night emergencies.  However, his tools are not sufficient to run a plumbing business. 

He is a hardworking and diligent man who says, "I work with my full resources, however there are times when I can't fix things due to my tools." 

He is requesting 1,000,000 MNT to buy tools.

loans.use: to buy tools.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 45 years old, married, and has two children. She is from San Jose, Aurora Zanboanga del Sur. 

To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a gardening business, planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been in this business for one year and she earn 2,000 PHP a month. 

In 2011, Evelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Evelyn hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

location.town: San Jose, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Maria Victoria

texts.es: La señora María, es nacida en la ciudad de Santa Cruz de la Sierra,  vive actualmente en la zona  Coronado.  Ella se dedica a la venta de comidas hace 1 año atrás, le va muy bien con esta actividad ya que esta es la única actividad con la que mantiene a su familia, tiene 4 hijos de los cuales ya 2 son independientes y dos siguen estudiando, La señora demuestra ser responsable en sus créditos anteriores. Ahora el crédito otorgado a la señora es para compra de mesas y sillas para ampliar su negocio ya que tiene muchos mas clientes y ella desea brindarles más comodidad a sus clientes ya que van por el trato amable que les brinda y por el buen sazón de que tiene la Sra. en la preparación de las comidas.
texts.en:
María is from the city Santa Cruz de la Sierra. She currently lives in the Coronado zone. She has been a food vendor for a year. Everything is going well for her with this activity, and it is the only activity that she uses to sustain the family. She has four children, two of whom are independent and two are still studying.

She has demonstrated her responsibility through her previous loans. Now the loan granted to her is for purchasing tables and chairs to grow her business. She has many more clients, and she wants them to be comfortable. They come to her because she is really friendly and because she does an excellent job preparing the dishes.

loans.use: purchase tables and chairs for her food stall

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en: Jonalyn is 25 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. Jonalyn has a shop that sells vegetables like eggplants and string beans. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan for 5,000 pesos to buy vegetables to sell. Jonalyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Jonalyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea is 43 years old. She operates a small business from her home for additional income while the main source of her revenue is generated from farming. She has four children, one of whom is married and lives separately while the other three are still students in local public schools. Mrs. Chea typically earns around $2 per day through farming to support her family.

Mrs. Chea will use her first loan from HKL to pay a fee to rent farmland. Chea hopes that one day she’ll own the farmland she rented from her neighbor as she strives to work harder.

loans.use: to pay a fee to rent farmland.

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 37 years old. He is married with 3 children aged between 5 and 13 years, they all go to school. He is a farmer and he has been doing for the past 6 years. With the loan from kiva, he would like to pay the workers who harvested beans. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house and pay school fees for his children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay the workers who harvested beans.

loans.name: Gabriela Del Carmen

texts.es: Gabriela es una mujer laboriosa, con muchas aspiraciones de crecer y prosperar en su negocio, tiene la edad de 21 años, madre soltera de un niño de dos años, su negocio es la venta de comida desde hace cuatro años y solicita por segundo ciclo el financiamiento en la institución para invertir en la compra de arroz, carne, bastimentos, vegetales y gaseosas. Su meta es maximizar sus ganancias, por otro lado con el crédito anterior logro abrir un nuevo local.

loans.use: para la compra de arroz, carne, bastimentos, vegetales y gaseosas

loans.name: Bibi Jan

texts.en:
Bibi Jan is 20 years old and lives with her 3 children in the Afshar Selow district of Kabul, Afghanistan.

She is married and would like a loan so she can work alongside her husband to enhance their financial situation.


She hopes to receive her first loan through AFSG so she can continue her husband's business and support her family in the future.

loans.use: To buy wood and flour for her husband's shop.

loans.name: Jacinto

texts.en:
Jacinto V. is one of the leaders in the rural community of Baba. He has lived in Baba his entire life and he is not only dedicated to making his farm successful, but also to helping those around him. He is a centerpiece in the Centro Agricola de Baba, which is the association that is forming the Communal Bank in the sector. As a borrower, Jacinto will invest his loan in rice farming, like most of the others in the communal bank. He will use the money to buy seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and also to rent machinery.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large multinational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice Farming

loans.name: Abdugaffur

texts.en: Abdugafuris is married and has 4 children. They all live with his parents. His parents are pensioners and his children go to school. Abdugafur and his wife earn money for his big familyby selling toys and children clothes. At first it was difficult to start but soon he expanded and developed his business well. He became a client of MicroInvest in 2005 and step-by-step he has increased the loan amount from $100 to $700. He and his wife have 2 places for trade in open-air market of  Mastchoh. Of course today they have constant clients and satisfied of their place. In the future Abdugafur plans to use a loan for buying seasonal (summer) goods.  He plans to use the profit for the reconstruction of his house. After that he can stay there with his family and one of the rooms he can equip for the shop. His parents and children can help him by the trading in this shop.

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Mrs. Pich N. is 46 years old. She and her husband have 7 children - 2 are garment workers, 1 is a security guard and the rest are students. Her husband works as an intermediary, buying and selling plots of land for $6 a day. Pich N. is a fish-selling street vendor, which currently earns her $25 a day. She would now like to increase her earnings by buying a great stock of fish, which will allow her to more effectively meet her clients’ demands.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for her inventory

loans.name: Thyda

texts.en:
Thyda M.  is married and has two sons. She learned to weave from her mother in 1990 and started her own silk production in the same year. Her husband is also weaving silk at home after being trained by his wife. To make extra income for the household, Thyda also sells homemade food from her home and raises pigs as well. 

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA two times already. She is now requesting a loan with the amount of $300. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and for fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Janet Roxana

texts.es:
Sra. Janet is a member of the Amigos Marcarinos ("Marcara-Area Friends") community bank. Her shop is located in Marcara's town market in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ancash. She sells general merchandise, at retail, along with fruits and vegetables, a business that she's been developing for four years. She has an enterprising, self-sacrificing spirit which has allowed her to fully commit to her family and customers.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.400 (400 Peruvian soles or about US$132), to be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy more products (rice, sugar, pasta, cooking oil and vegetables) to better stock her business.

Sra. Janet, 25, thriving at business, like anyone who aspires to improve themselves, has two small children. Her husband is a bus driver on a route that ends at the Banos Termales de Chancos ("Chancos Thermal Baths"). This has allowed her to meet more people and increase her customer base. She tries not to miss a chance to add new customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Janet es socia del Banco Comunal Amigos Marcarinos, su local de venta se encuentra dentro del mercado del Distrito de Marcara, Provincia de Carhuaz, Departamento de Ancash, vende abarrotes al por menor combinando con verduras y frutas, actividad que viene desarrollando desde hace cuatro años. Ella tiene espíritu emprendedor y abnegado, ello le ha permitido que hoy se sienta comprometida con su familia y con sus clientes.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 400.00 ($ 132) que será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más productos (un saco de Arroz, un saco de Azúcar, una bolsa de fideos, una caja de aceite y diversas verduras), con estos productos podrá surtir mejor su negocio.

La señora Janet tiene 25 años, prospera negociante como cualquier persona que aspira seguir superándose, tiene dos hijos pequeños, su esposo es chofer de colectivos que tienen como destino los Baños Termales de Chancos. Esta actividad le ha permitido conocer mas personas e incrementar sus clientes, trata de no perder la oportunidad de aumentar su clientela.

loans.use: Buy general merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana is a 38 year old married mother who looks after her own 4 children as well as 4 orphans. Most orphans here are the relatives of the people who care for them. Uganda was one of the earliest and hardest hit countries in the ongoing AIDS epidemic. It is believed that the first outbreak of HIV/AIDS occurred in the area near Ntungamo near the border of the Congo and Rwanda. Uganda is a country with a “missing generation” of people between the ages of 35-55. To its credit, Uganda recognized the crisis early and the occurrence of AIDS in the country has dropped from a high of 26%-33% in Kampala in the late 1980s to a current country wide occurrence of around 5%-7%.

For the past four years, Diana has operated a restaurant specializing in goat meat. She buys a goat for between 25,000 to 35,000 shillings or $15 to $20, slaughters it herself and serves one to two goats per week. The goat population is plentiful in this area and you constantly hear the bleating of a herd going down the road. Diana also serves the typical Ugandan food of matooke, rice, etc. With her loan, Diana plans to buy, more goats for her restaurant.

loans.use: Diana plans to use her loan to buy more goats.

loans.name: Kagugube C Group

texts.en:
Rose is 34 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a business man. Rose has a drug store. With the extra profits, she intends to start up a clinic with matenity section. She usually earns shs. 60, 000 profits each week. Catherine, Jenifer and Aisha all have retail shop business. Winnie owns a beauty salon.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs

loans.name: Muguluka West G Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mwajuma M.. She is currently in the business of selling second hand clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Mwajuma is 35 years old and is a widow. She has 8 children ranging from age 6 to 23 and all of them go to school. Each week, Mwajuma makes approximately UGX 13000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to improve business. Mwajuma has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to boost business and the loan was paid back on time.

Mwajuma is joined in her small group by Zulaika N. and Hadija N.. Zulaika N. has a business selling sugar wax and wants to add capital and boost business. Hadija N. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to increase stock in her shop.

loans.use: To boost clothing business

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.es:
Trinidad Hernández is a seamstress. She started her business more than 5 years ago with a sewing machine that her mother lent her in order to generate extra income to pay for various financial family needs since they weren't making ends meet with her husband's salary alone. He works as a high school teacher; their 4 children devote themselves to their studies and are 14, 13, 9, and 7 years old.

Faced with a lack of money to remodel her tailor shop, she asks for a loan of $950 USD that she will repay in 6 months. With your help, Trini's children will be able to continue with their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Trinidad Hernández es costurera inicio su negocio hace mas de 5 años, con una maquina de coser que su madre le presto para que generara un ingreso extra para cubrir varias necesidades económicas de su familia ya que con el sueldo de su esposo no completaban, el se desempeña como maestro de secundaria, sus 4 hijos se dedican a estudiar tienen 14, 13,9 y 7 años.

Ante la falta de dinero para remodelar su taller de costura es que ella solicita un crédito por US $950 que pagara en 6 meses. Con tu ayuda los hijos de Trini podrán seguir estudiando.

loans.use: Remodel her workshop

loans.name: Andrez

texts.es:
Andrez' family is comprised of two people, he and his wife (who is currently pregnant). Andrez runs a transportation business - he transports people by motorcycle in his town, but considers that he possesses a "medium" skill level, because there are others who are engaged in the same business.

This loan request is for the purchase of a new bike. The price varies depending on the year, make and engine capacity. His credit history is very favorable, and all previous loans have been paid off in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

La familia de Andrez está compuesta por dos personas, él y su esposa que actualmente está embarazada. Andrez se dedica al transporte de pasajeros en la zona de Warnes como mototaxista, su nivel de competencia es medio debido a que hay otras personas que se dedican a la misma actividad. La presente solicitud es para la compra de una nueva moto, el precio de la misma varia dependiendo el año, la marca y la cilindrada. Sus antecedentes crediticios son muy buenos ya que los créditos que obtuvo con anterioridad los canceló de manera puntual.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for his transportation business. (Compra de moto nueva)

loans.name: Ni Luh

texts.id:
This is Ni Luh S.'s 2nd loan from Dinari. She is able to improve her business from her 1st loan. After the 1st loan, Ni Luh S. is now also selling her rice dish at another place (not only at one place). She also sells coffee and cold drinks at her stall in addition to her rice dish.

She opens her food stall nearby a construction project site in Denpasar so the construction workers can buy food and coffee from her. She opens her stall from the morning to the evening.

Her long term goal is to open a permanent stall so she doesn't have to move around from one construction project sites to another.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Pinjaman kali ini merupakan pinjaman ke-2 bagi Ni Luh S. dari DINARI. Pada pinjaman sebelumnya, sudah ada peningkatan usah, walaupun masih belum terlalu besar. Biasanya Ni Luh hanya berjualan nasi disatu tempat, tetapi kali ini sudah mulai berjualan ditempat lain. Kalau sebelumnya hanya berjualan nasi, kali ini sudah ada kopi, es dan minuman lainnya. Dia berjualan disekitar proyek di Denpasar, dimana para buruh proyek suka membeli makan dan kopi. Dari pagi sampai sore dia menekuni pekerjaan ini. Dia berkeinginan, suatu saat dia bisa membuka satu tempat sendiri sehingga dia tidak berpindah-pindah lagi berjualan.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Maryam's Group

texts.en:
Maryam baji is a wife of M. T. and lives in a city named Arifwala located in Pakistan. (Baji is an Urdu term meaning 'elder sister'.) She is a mother of six children; five sons and one daughter. The family lives in a two-room brick house.

Her husband is a tailor and has been in this profession for the last five years. The eldest son has a shop where he presses clothes and the daughter makes clothes to order. Maryam baji has a wish to give her remaining children a good education. She is applying for this loan to help expand her husband and her son’s businesses.

There are three other members in her loan group. Both members named Sakina baji want a loan to buy a donkey cart. Azizan baji wants a loan to start a Pan Shop (drink corner).

The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her particular business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To facilitate the people through their skills

loans.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana is the owner of a mototaxi and also sells chickens. She has two minor children who are still in school. Her husband José is the one in charge of the care of the mototaxi and he uses it to transport passengers. These two parents dedicate their efforts to their children’s future, and both of them know that the children depend on them to become good men. Susana has turned to you to request a loan for which part will be used to repair the mototaxi and the other part will be used to increase their capital for their chicken business. In the future, they want to build their own stall where they can sell their chickens and be more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Susana es propietaria de un motocarro, y también se dedica a la venta de pollo, ella tiene 2 hijos menores que aún estudian. Su esposo el señor José es quien se dedica al cuidado de su motocarro y lo maneja haciendo transporte de pasajeros. Estos dos padres dedican su esfuerzo para el futuro de sus hijos, ambos saben que de ellos depende que sean hombres de bien.Susana se dirige a ustedes para solicitar un préstamo, el cual usará para la reparación de su motocarro y otra parte para incrementar el capital de su negocio de pollo, para en un futuro poder construir su propio puesto de venta y tener una mayor comodidad.

loans.use: Repair their mototaxi and have more capital for their chicken business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Công 53 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1999. Qua gần 10 năm vay vốn kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển, vay vốn của Quỹ chủ yếu gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, ban đầu gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Kết quả từ việc chăn nuôi lợn gia đình chị đã đầu tư thêm vào mô hình chăn nuôi bò sinh sản và bò phối giống. Viêc kinh doanh bò phối giống đã đem lại hiệu quả kinh tế cao cho gia đình chị, bà con quanh vùng trong địa phương đều lấy giống bò của gia đình chị, bò sinh sản đều đặn mỗi năm được xuất 1 lứa bò con. Kết quả từ việc chăn nuôi gia đình chị đã xây dựng gia đình cho 4 người con, và đều được chị xây cho mỗi người một dinh cơ khang trang. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 10.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư mua bò sinh sản.
Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi C., aged 53, joined TYM Fund in 1999. After 10 years of membership, her family’s financial situation has been enhanced a lot and keeps getting better and better. Mrs. C.’s purpose in asking for loans is usually to invest in breeding poultries. She used the loan of the first round to raise pigs; the profits she then used to raise cows. Raising cows has been very profitable for the family as people in her neighborhood and adjacent areas regularly buy them. Mrs. C. and her husband have four children, all of whom are married and live independently. In the next round of loan, Mrs. C. would like to borrow 10.000.000 VND ($625) to buy more cows. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka J. was born in 1966. She is divorced and she has one child. She is employed in a bakery and she earns there 350 KM monthly. Milka works, also, on agriculture and from this she earns 200 KM in a month.

Milka wants to make better life for her child, so she decided to take a loan with Women for Women International in the amount of 600 KM ($US450). She will use this loan to buy food for poultry and pigs. After a few months she will sell some of the poultry and a pig and she hopes to earn in this way. Her wish is to makes her little business with poultry and pigs.

loans.use: To buy food for poultry and pigs.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.es: Su labor diaria es dar una buena atención a sus clientes, sobre todo ver que sus productos estén al alcance D. sus bolsillos, Nilda se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes y productos D. primera necesidad.  A sus 55 años, es madre D. 6 hijos que ya son independientes y trabajan, gracias a la buena educación y apoyo que les brindó, su esposo Roger es quien la apoya en todo y siempre está al  pendiente D. ella, sobre todo con las decisiones del negocio. Inició este negocio debido a que se encuentra ubicada en un lugar muy transitable.  Nilda se trazó el objetivo D. seguir creciendo y ampliar su bodega, sin embargo, estima D. un capital para lograr su meta. Apoyemos a esta madre que trabaja duro por salir adelante.
texts.en:
Her daily work is to proviD. good service to her clients and, above all, to see that her products are at prices that suit any pocketbook. Nilda sells groceries and primary need products. At 55 years of age, she is the mother of 6 children who are now independent and work, thanks to the good education and support she gave them. Her husband, Roger, is someone that supports her in everything and always is by her siD., above all in her business decisions. She started this business because she found that it was located in a highly trafficked place. Nilda, has set as her goal to continue growing and expanding her shop. Nevertheless, she needs some capital to meet her goal. We support this mother who works hard to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the merchandise in her shop and also to expand and improve the space.

loans.name: Maria Virginia

texts.es:
La señora María Virginia tiene 44 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Empresarias de Éxito II  y vive en la calle Manuel Cox 107  del Asentamiento Humano Aurora Díaz del Puerto de Salaverry provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
María estudió primaria completa, pero no le gustaba estudiar se inclinó siempre por los negocios y no continuó estudiando. Se casó de 15 años y tiene 2 hijos, cada uno con su compromiso, ella actualmente cuida a un  nieto.
María trabaja haciendo almuerzos para vender, lo que normalmente llamamos menú, además vende gaseosa, el negocio se ubica en su casa.
Con el primer préstamo de 300 soles que devolvió en 4 cuotas compró arroz, azúcar y aceite.
Con este crédito de 800 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas comprará, arroz, azúcar, gaseosa y cerveza, para los piqueos de los sábados y domingos, manifiesta.
María Virginia tiene una casa que aun está inconclusa por falta de medios económicos, sueña con terminarla y ponerla muy bonita, para poder cobijar a sus hijos y nietos.
texts.en:
